benefits.title: Editors' note: Nutrients and bioactives in green leafy vegetables and cognitive decline: Prospective study
benefits.summary: A high intake of green leafy vegetables protects against cognitive decline and may influence the gut microbiome to decrease inflammation and the development of neurodegenerative disease.

benefits.title: Nutritional Profile and Potential Health Benefits of Super Foods: A Review
benefits.summary: Superfoods exhibit positive effects, preventing ailments, providing impetus to the immune system, and providing essential macro- and micro-nutrients in ample quantities.

benefits.title: Antioxidant characterization of some Sicilian edible wild greens.
benefits.summary: Wild greens are rich in antioxidants, such as flavonoids and carotenoids, with high total antioxidant capacity (TAC) values, which may protect against cancers and cardiovascular disease.
benefits.journal: Journal of agricultural and food chemistry

benefits.title: Extraction and Natural Bioactive Molecules Characterization in Spinach, Kale and Purslane: A Comparative Study
benefits.summary: Leafy greens like spinach, kale, and purslane contain essential nutrients and can reduce the risk of many chronic diseases.

benefits.title: Superfoods and their role in disease prevention
benefits.summary: Superfoods, like fruits, are nutrient-dense and rich in bioactive compounds, which can promote health and prevent the development of diseases when consumed as part of a balanced diet and healthy lifestyle.

benefits.title: Emerging Functional Beverages: Fruit Wines and Transgenic Wines
benefits.summary: Regular consumption of green tea, probiotics, and prebiotic-enriched beverages is associated with decreased risk of lifestyle diseases, including decreased risk of heart disease and cancer.

benefits.title: Carotenoids in Green Vegetables and Health Aspects
benefits.summary: Green vegetables are good sources of vitamins and minerals, and carotenoids may help prevent chronic diseases like heart disease, cancer, and eye diseases.

benefits.title: Functional Food with Some Health Benefits, So Called Superfood: A Review
benefits.summary: Superfoods reduce the risk of degenerative diseases by promoting physical and emotional health, and are a dense source of antioxidants, minerals, vitamins, and other nutrients.

benefits.title: Superfood: Value and Need
benefits.summary: Superfoods like quinoa, goji berry, and acai berry have increased nutritional efficiency and more antioxidants, leading to the prevention of coronary heart diseases.

benefits.title: The concept of superfoods in diet
benefits.summary: Superfoods like goji, camu-camu, quinoa, chia seeds, flaxseeds, maqui, acai, pomegranate, mangosteen, cocoa, and spirulina combine functional properties with individual exotic and natural properties, offering extreme health
benefits.journal: The Role of Alternative and Innovative Food Ingredients and Products in Consumer Wellness

side effects.title: Editors' note: Nutrients and bioactives in green leafy vegetables and cognitive decline: Prospective study
side effects.summary: A high intake of green leafy vegetables protects against cognitive decline and may influence the gut microbiome to decrease inflammation and the development of neurodegenerative disease.

side effects.title: Influence of Green Leafy Vegetables in Diets with an Elevated ω-6:ω-3 Fatty Acid Ratio on Rat Blood Pressure, Plasma Lipids, Antioxidant Status and Markers of Inflammation
side effects.summary: Consumption of green leafy vegetables like collard greens, purslane, and sweetpotato greens can decrease risks for cardiovascular disease associated with diets with an elevated -6:-3 fatty acid ratio.

side effects.title: A randomized clinical trial of the effects of leafy green vegetables and inorganic nitrate on blood pressure
side effects.summary: Leafy green vegetables or pills containing the same amount of inorganic nitrate do not decrease ambulatory blood pressure in subjects with elevated blood pressure.
side effects.journal: The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition

side effects.title: Phytochemical Composition of the Decoctions of Greek Edible Greens (Chórta) and Evaluation of Antioxidant and Cytotoxic Properties
side effects.summary: Greek edible greens are a rich source of bioactive secondary metabolites and their consumption could contribute to the maintenance of overall health.
side effects.journal: Molecules : A Journal of Synthetic Chemistry and Natural Product Chemistry

side effects.title: Influence of carotene-rich vegetable meals on the prevalence of anaemia and iron deficiency in Filipino schoolchildren
side effects.summary: Carotene-rich yellow and green leafy vegetables improve total-body vitamin A pool size, haemoglobin concentration, and decrease anemia rates in Filipino schoolchildren, with no effect on iron deficiency or iron-deficiency anemia rates.

side effects.title: Nutritional Profile and Potential Health Benefits of Super Foods: A Review
side effects.summary: Superfoods exhibit positive effects, preventing ailments, providing impetus to the immune system, and providing essential macro- and micro-nutrients in ample quantities.

side effects.title: Epigallocatechin-3-Gallate Toxicity in Children: A Potential and Current Toxicological Event in the Differential Diagnosis With Virus-Triggered Fulminant Hepatic Failure
side effects.summary: Epigallocatechin-3-gallate, a major component of green tea, may cause toxicity in children, particularly affecting the liver due to immaturity of hepatocytes.

side effects.title: Nutritional composition and flavonoid content of edible wild greens and green pies: a potential rich source of antioxidant nutrients in the Mediterranean diet
side effects.summary: Wild greens and green pies are a rich source of antioxidant flavonols and flavones in the Greek diet.

side effects.title: Iron bioavailability in green leafy vegetables cooked in different utensils
side effects.summary: Cooking in iron utensils increases the total and available iron content of greens.

side effects.title: Nutritional Composition and Bioactive Components in Quinoa (Chenopodium quinoa Willd.) Greens: A Review
side effects.summary: Quinoa greens have health promoting properties such as being antimicrobial, anticancer, antidiabetic, antioxidant, antiobesity, and cardio-beneficial.

dosage.title: Determination of beta-carotene and lutein available from green leafy vegetables by an in vitro digestion and colonic fermentation method.
dosage.summary: Green leafy vegetables contain 27-52 mg of beta-carotene and 140-193 mg of lutein per 100g of dry sample.
dosage.journal: Journal of agricultural and food chemistry

dosage.title: Potential of commonly consumed green leafy vegetables for their antioxidant capacity and its linkage with the micronutrient profile
dosage.summary: Green leafy vegetables have a large variability in antioxidant activity, with values ranging from 1.5-5.6 mM vitamin E/100 g for raw samples and 1.6-3.8 mM vitamin E/100 g for cooked samples.
dosage.journal: International Journal of Food Sciences and Nutrition

dosage.title: Polyphenol Extract of Greens+™ Nutritional Supplement Stimulates Bone Formation in Cultures of Human Osteoblast-like SaOS-2 Cells
dosage.summary: 1.2–2.0 mg greens+TM extract/ml stimulated mineralized bone nodule formation in a dose and time dependent manner.

dosage.title: Increase in serum beta-carotene following dark green leafy vegetable supplementation in Mebendazole-treated school children in Bangladesh
dosage.summary: A moderately high cumulative dose of dark green leafy vegetables (4.4 mg) for 6 weeks significantly increased serum beta-carotene in children treated for Ascaris lumbricoides.

dosage.title: The Contribution of Wild Plants to Dietary Intakes of Micronutrients (II): Mineral Elements
dosage.summary: Wild greens and fruits may provide Ca, Mg, Fe, and Mn amounts reaching 50% of daily requirements, and K and Cu levels reaching 30% of the recommendations.

dosage.title: A randomized clinical trial of the effects of leafy green vegetables and inorganic nitrate on blood pressure
dosage.summary: Leafy green vegetables containing 300 mg nitrate or pills containing the same amount of inorganic nitrate do not decrease ambulatory blood pressure in subjects with elevated blood pressure.
dosage.journal: The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition

dosage.title: Influence of carotene-rich vegetable meals on the prevalence of anaemia and iron deficiency in Filipino schoolchildren
dosage.summary: Carotene-rich yellow and green leafy vegetables containing 4.2 mg of provitamin A carotenoids per day improved total-body vitamin A pool size, Hb concentration, and decreased anemia rates in Filipino schoolchildren.

dosage.title: Analysis of nutrient and antinutrient content of underutilized green leafy vegetables
dosage.summary: Four green leafy vegetables had high iron content (13.15–17.72 mg/100 g), while the rest had lower levels (2.62–9.86 mg/100 g).

dosage.title: Lack of improvement in vitamin A status with increased consumption of dark-green leafy vegetables
dosage.summary: An additional daily portion of dark-green leafy vegetables did not improve vitamin A status, but a similar amount of beta-carotene from a simpler matrix produced a strong improvement.

dosage.title: In Vitro and in Vivo Antioxidant Properties of the Plant-Based Supplement Greens+™
dosage.summary: Greens+ supplementation increased serum antioxidant potential at higher levels of intake in a dose-dependent manner.
